content.text: Dementia is a condition that affects the brain and makes it harder for a person to remember things, think clearly, solve problems or manage daily activities. It happens when brain cells are damaged by certain diseases and get worse over time. The symptoms can be different for each person, depending on which parts of the brain are affected. While people with dementia stay awake and aware, they may also go through changes in their mood, emotions, behaviour or motivation, sometimes even before memory problems begin. In Malaysia, about 850,000 people are currently living with dementia.
Alzheimer's Disease

items: The most common cause of dementia, making up about 60–70% of all cases.

Alzheimer's disease happens when certain proteins build up in the brain, damaging brain cells and the connections between them. Over time, these cells start to die, leading to memory loss and changes in thinking.
The first sign is often difficulty remembering recent events, but people may also find it hard to find the right words, solve problems, make decisions or understand things like distance and space.

content.text: Vascular Dementia

items: Vascular dementia happens when the brain doesn't get enough blood and oxygen because some blood vessels become blocked or narrowed. This can damage brain cells and usually occurs after a major stroke or several small strokes.

People with vascular dementia may find it harder to plan, stay focused, solve problems or think as quickly as before. At times, they might also feel suddenly confused, but these moments can come and go.

content.text: Dementia with Lewy Bodies

items: Dementia with Lewy bodies happens when tiny abnormal structures, called Lewy bodies, build up inside brain cells. These affect how the brain works and eventually cause brain cells to die.

People with this dementia may notice that their alertness or attention changes throughout the day. They might seem sharp at one moment and confused the next. They may also experience visual hallucinations (seeing things that aren't really there) or have trouble judging distances.
This condition is closely related to Parkinson's disease, so some people may also have movement problems, such as stiffness, slow movement or trembling.

content.text: Frontotemporal Dementia

items: Frontotemporal dementia happens when the front and side parts of the brain are damaged by a buildup of abnormal proteins that cause brain cells to die.

The first signs are often changes in personality or behaviour. The person may act differently than usual or seem less aware of social boundaries. Depending on which parts of the brain are affected, they may also have trouble speaking smoothly or understanding the meaning of words.
This type of dementia often occurs at a younger age.

content.text: Mixed Dementia

items: Mixed dementia happens when a person has more than one type of dementia, such as Alzheimer's and vascular dementia. This causes a mix of symptoms from the different dementia types like memory loss, confusion and thinking problems.

content.text: Rare Causes of Dementia

items: Dementia can also develop from other causes, such as after a stroke, certain infections like HIV, heavy alcohol use, repeated head injuries or severe nutritional deficiencies.

content.text: Dementia can show up in many different ways, such that no two people experience it exactly the same. The symptoms depend on the cause, the person's overall health and how their brain was working before the illness began. Early signs may be subtle and easy to overlook, but they often become clearer over time. Below are some common symptoms and changes that may occur.
Memory Loss and Forgetfulness

items: Forgetting recent events or conversations
Misplacing items or losing things more often
Getting lost while walking or driving in familiar places
Forgetting names of friends or everyday objects
Struggling to remember things seen, heard or read recently

content.text: Confusion and Communication Difficulties

items: Feeling confused, even in familiar surroundings
Losing track of time or day
Finding it hard to follow conversations or TV programmes
Forgetting what you were saying midway through a sentence
Trouble finding the right words when speaking

content.text: Thinking, Problem-Solving and Daily Tasks

items: Difficulty making decisions or solving problems
Struggling to perform familiar tasks
Problems with judging distances or seeing things clearly
Trouble thinking logically or planning ahead

content.text: Mood and Behavior Changes

items: Feeling anxious, sad or frustrated about memory loss
Personality changes or acting differently from usual
Inappropriate or out-of-character behaviour
Withdrawing from work, hobbies or social activities
Showing less interest in the feelings of others

content.text: Over time, symptoms may become more severe. The person may need help with personal care and everyday activities. They might experience the following changes.

items: Struggle to recognize family and friends
Have trouble walking or moving around
Lose control of their bladder or bowels
Find it hard to eat or drink
Experience mood swings or aggressive behaviour, which can be distressing for both the person and their loved ones

content.text: Diagnosing dementia involves several steps and it's usually done by specialistdoctor such as a psychiatrist, geriatrician or neurologist.

items: The doctor will talk with the person and someone close to them to understand the changes that have developed and how these are affecting daily life.
Simple tests, such as the Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) or the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA), are typically used to check memory and thinking skills.
Blood tests may be done to rule out other causes of memory problems, such as thyroid issues or vitamin deficiencies.
In some cases, an MRI scan is recommended to look for changes or damage in the brain that can help confirm the diagnosis.

content.text: If you or someone you know is showing signs of dementia, it is important to seek help early from a healthcare professional. A doctor can assess the situation, provide guidance and connect you with the right support. You can also visit the Alzheimer's Disease Foundation Malaysia (ADFM) website for more information, resources and local support services.

items: Supportive Treatments and Lifestyle Approaches

content.text: While there is currently no cure for dementia, many daily habits and supportive activities can help improve quality of life and slow the progression of symptoms.

items: Cognitive and memory activities: Puzzles, reading or memory games will help to keep the mind active
Routine and structure: Keep a regular daily routine to reduce confusion and stress

Physical activity: Regular exercise like walking, stretching or light workouts can boost mood, sleep and overall brain health. If the person you're caring for has mobility issues, chair-based exercises are good alternatives to maintain physical activities.
Healthy eating: A balanced diet rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains and lean proteins supports brain function
Social engagement: Staying connected with family, friends or community groups help reduce loneliness
Occupational and speech therapy: Professionals can provide strategies to improve communication, safety and independence at home
Medication

content.text: Medicines may be helpful for some types of dementia, but not all. They can ease certain symptoms, such as memory or thinking problems, and may help with mood or behaviour changes. However, they cannot cure dementia or stop it from progressing. Your doctor will explain which treatments, if any, are suitable and help you decide what's best for your needs.

subsections.title: The Role of a Dementia Caregiver

content.text: Most dementia caregivers are family members or close friends who step in out of love and responsibility. Their role is to protect the person's dignity, comfort and daily well-being. At first, this may mean giving reminders and helping with simple routines, but over time it often grows into providing full personal, medical and emotional care. Caregivers also become advocates, planning healthcare and future needs. In Malaysia, caregiving is usually shared among family members, with at least two caregivers recommended to reduce burnout.
Daily care

items: Caregivers help with bathing, grooming, dressing, toileting, meals and medication
Encourage independence where possible but step in when safety or memory issues make it necessary

content.text: Safety

items: Homes must be adapted - removing hazards, preventing wandering and arranging safe transport when driving is no longer possible

content.text: Routine and activities

items: Keeping a predictable daily schedule reduces agitation
Activities like listening to music, keeping photo albums, solving puzzles or simple chores can bring joy and preserve memory
When the dementia progresses, adjust the routine/ activities according to the capabilities of the person you're caring for

content.text: Behavior management

items: Agitation often comes from triggers like noise, tiredness or hunger
Caregivers should learn to respond calmly, reassure instead of argue, and adjust routines to reduce stress

content.text: Communication and companionship

items: Speaking slowly, using short sentences and close-ended questions
Use touch or smiles can convey trust and love
Small moments of shared presence, such as walking, sitting together, looking at old photos, will help reduce loneliness

content.text: Healthcare and planning

items: Caregivers track symptoms, attend appointments and discuss long-term treatment preferences (Advanced Care Planning) early
They also handle financial matters, including managing their bank accounts andsetting up legal documents such as Power of Attorney

content.text: Caring for someone with dementia can be exhausting. Many caregivers face constant stress, sleep disruption and emotional turmoil — grief, guilt, frustration or sadness as their loved one changes over time. The physical demands, like lifting or moving the person, can harm their own health, while social isolation and loss of personal time often deepen the strain.

No one should carry the weight alone. Sharing duties with family, joining support groups and accessing local organizations can make a big difference. In Malaysia, the Alzheimer's Disease Foundation (ADFM), Penang Dementia Association (PDA), The Dementia Society Perak and Johor Bahru Alzheimer's Disease Support Association (JOBADA)offer helplines, caregiver trainings and daycare options. Respite care options such as day centers or short-term carers give families much-needed breaks. Professional advice from doctors, therapists or legal and financial experts can also ease the burden.

items: Prepare early by learning practical skills from resources like "iSupport for Dementia" (developed by World Health Organisation) or ADFM workshops
Keep routines consistent to reduce confusion
Use clear and simple communication, using short sentences and close-ended questions
Make the home safe with labels, ensure sufficient brightness in the house, and clutter-free spaces
Encourage small tasks to maintain independence and dignity
Plan finances and legal matters early. Discuss advanced care planning with the person you're caring for as early as possible.
Look after your own health — rest, checkups and accepting help are essential
Build a support network, whether in-person or online, and use technology like reminder apps to stay organized

content.text: Caring for a person with dementia can be both meaningful and challenging. Understanding their daily needs, communication styles and behavioural changes can make caregiving smoother and more compassionate. This section provides key practical tips from WHO's "iSupport for Dementia" modules and dementia associations to help caregivers provide safe and supportive care, while maintaining their own wellbeing.
Providing consistent and respectful care helps maintain comfort, dignity and quality of life for persons with dementia.
Meals and Hydration

items: Encourage regular eating and drinking
Modify food texture and utensils if needed
Involve the person in mealtime activities, such as setting up tables, washing, meal prepping
Monitor for swallowing difficulties or weight loss

Appetite loss is common among persons with dementia, as dementia may disrupt their sense of taste and smell. Look out for other causes such as exhaustion, sickness, medication side effects, confusion caused by distracting environment, or constipation.

content.text: Toileting and Continence

items: Support with empathy, understanding that they may feel embarrassed for needing toileting assistance from you
Respect their privacy
Use clear toilet signs, regular schedules and proper hygiene care to prevent infections and discomfort

content.text: Personal Care

items: Assist with bathing, dressing and grooming while promoting independence wherever safe and possible
Use a calm and gentle approach to reduce agitation.
Try not to force them to do something they do not wish to. Walk away from the argument, come back and try again later.

content.text: Daily Routines

items: Maintain predictable schedules to reduce anxiety and confusion
Familiar activities like music, light exercise or reminiscence help keep the person engaged and reassured

content.text: Effective communication is key to understanding people with dementia and meeting their needs.

items: Use simple and clear sentences
Speak slowly and maintain eye contact
Reduce distractions and ensure hearing aids or glasses are used correctly
Avoid correcting mistakes harshly. Focus on reassurance and emotional connection to prevent arguments
Pay attention to non-verbal cues like tone, gestures and facial expressions
Offer praise and encouragement to support confidence and self-esteem

content.text: Behavioural changes are symptoms of dementia, not intentional actions. Understanding triggers and responding calmly can help manage them.
Memory Loss

items: Use reminders, notes and calendar
Stick to consistent routines as much as possible
Reassure instead of correcting

content.text: Aggression or Agitation

items: Aggression and agitation often stem from fear, pain or confusion
Avoid arguing. Try to Remain calm and redirect their attention
If you find yourself agitating, walk away from the situation, take few deep breaths, and come back to the situation when you're calmer

content.text: Depression, Anxiety and Apathy

items: Encourage social interaction and pleasant activities
Seek professional support if symptoms persist (e.g. psychologist)

content.text: Wandering

items: Ensure safety with ID bracelets, secured doors and supervised walks

content.text: Delusions and Hallucinations

items: Avoid arguing, instead reassure and distract
Adjust lighting or noise if environmental triggers exist

content.text: Repetitive behaviour

items: Redirect to safe, purposeful activities and respond with patience

content.text: Judgement changes

items: Anticipate risky behaviour
Adapt the environment and use "dementia cards" to explain situations to others if needed in public

content.text: A safe and supportive environment helps reduce confusion and accidents

items: Create a dementia-friendly home with clear lighting, uncluttered spaces and labelled rooms to aid recognition
Use non-slip mats, stable furniture and visual contrast (e.g. bright plates or toilet seats with colour contrasts)
Check regularly for health issues like infections, falls or swallowing problems
Keep emergency contacts and medical information easily accessible

content.text: Caring for someone with dementia can be emotionally and physically demanding — Carers need care too!

items: Take breaks and maintain your own health through rest, exercise and hobbies
Join caregiver support groups (e.g., ADFM, Penang Dementia Association) to share experiences and gain guidance
Don't hesitate to seek help from family, friends or professional respite services
Educate yourself about dementia to reduce uncertainty and stress
Discuss and plan ahead for future care, finances and preferences early to avoid crisis decisions when the time comes

content.text: Caring for someone with dementia often takes a lot of time, energy and patience. Caregivers might forget to care for themselves. This section shares simple ways to look after your own well-being. You will learn easy relaxation exercises to help you feel calmer and ideas for doing enjoyable activities that give you energy. We also provide tips on how to think more positively about difficult situations. Remember, taking care of yourself helps you stay healthy and continue caring for your loved one.
Basic Breathing (< 5 mins): Helps reduce tension

items: Sit or stand up straight with both feet flat on the floor
Focus on your breathing
Put your hand on your stomach to feel it rise and fall with each breath
Exhale from your mouth and pull your stomach in
Repeat for a few breaths, then rest

content.text: Mindful Breathing Technique (5 mins): Reduces stress and helps you focus
https://youtube.com/shorts/y9jbHCRq9Ho?si=IfwbMA3C568KQ9A7

items: Sit straight with relaxed shoulders
Breathe in through your stomach for 4 counts
Hold for 7 counts
Breathe out for 8 counts
Practice listening to your own thoughts without negative judgement

content.text: Neck Movements (5 mins): Releases tension and improves blood flow

items: Move slowly and gently
Nod forward and backward (inhale up, exhale down)
Turn your head side to side (inhale center, exhale side)
Drop your ear to your shoulder (inhale center, exhale drop)
Repeat 5 times

content.text: Total Stretching (10 mins): Do it at any time at any where

items: Stand up or sit tall in your chair
Take slow, deep breaths — feel the tension leave your body as you exhale
Stretch your arms to the sides, in front, and up toward the sky
Feel your back, shoulders, and arms loosen with each stretch
Roll your shoulders back three times, then forward three times
Shrug your shoulders up and down a few times
Finish with one deep, relaxing breath — release all remaining tension

content.text: You can take time to relax anywhere and at any time of the day. Try setting a goal to practice a relaxation exercise at least once daily, and if it helps, schedule a specific time  using a reminder. Even a brief exercise can make a noticeable difference – helping you feel refreshed, improving your mood and reducing feelings of tension.

Doing things that you enjoy such as going for a walk, talking to a friend or listening to music can help you relax and recharge. Because caregiving can last a long time, it's important to take time for pleasant activities so you can continue providing care over the long term. Here is a list of common challenges that you may often face when trying to find time for yourself:
Barriers
How to Overcome It
No Time

Choose short, simple activities that you enjoy. Create priority list and let go of non-urgent tasks, e.g. ask yourself if cleaning every day is really necessary. You might find you have more time than you thought.
No Energy
Even if it's hard to imagine, doing something you enjoy can actually give you more energy and lift your mood.
No Money
Many pleasant activities are free, e.g. walking, chatting with a friend or listening to music.
Not in the Mood
Your mood often improves after doing something pleasant. Try starting small — even a few minutes can make a difference.
Feeling Guilty
Taking time to relax and do things you enjoy is not selfish, but it helps you provide better care. Being a good carer means caring for yourself too!
How you think about an event affects how you feel. One way of dealing with stressful events is to think differently. You cannot change what happens, but you can change your response.
Lost Keys - An example that shows how helpful thoughts can make it easier to respond to difficult situations

items: Jo is married to Max who is living with dementia.
One day, Jo is about to leave the house to visit a friend. Max says, "I can't find my keys! You cannot leave me without keys!"
Jo thinks to herself, "I cannot leave him alone anymore." She starts to feel miserable.
This means that Jo is thinking in an unhelpful way. It will be harder to respond in useful ways to situations like this.

Instead, Jo could think, "Max has dementia and is sometimes worried when he loses things. I can take some time to help and then go." This different way of thinking will probably make Jo feel better and help her stay calm and compassionate.

content.text: Unhelpful Thoughts
Helpful Thoughts
I have to do everything alone
Asking for help from others can help me to share the burden of care
When the person I care for is not happy, it means that I am a bad carer
Dementia is a disease. It is not mine or anyone else's fault
I must always be available for the person I care for
It is okay to take time to relax as it will help me to provide a good standard of care
I should not consider my own needs if I want to be a good carer
Making time for myself is important, as it helps me to provide better care
No one understands how hard it is to care
Sharing my feelings with others helps to take the pressure off
